div1.ab: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, Northern Division.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF LEE FONG FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
J. M. Wiestling, for the Petitioner. Ellis D. Buller, for the Respondent.
div1.p: The petitioner, Lee Fong, was arrested and detained in the custody of the Chief of Police of the City of Seattle, upon the charge that he had violated the provisions of Section 6 of Ordinance 710 of the City of Seattle, approved Feb. 6, 1886, entitled: An ordinance regulating the establishment and maintainance of public laundries and public wash-houses within the limits of the City of Seattle" Those portions of the ordinance which are pertinent to the present inquire read as follows: "Sec. 2. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to conduct or maintain a public laundry or wash-house within the city of Seattle without having first obtained a certificate signed by the health officer of the city of Seattle that the premises are properly and sufficiently drained and that all proper arrangements for carrying on the business without injury to the sanitary condition of the neighborhood have been complied with, also a certificate signed by the chief of the fire department of the City

of Seattle that the stoves, washing and drying apparatus and the appliances for heating smoothing irons are in good condition, and that their use is not dangerous to the surrounding property, from fire, and that all proper precautions have been taken to comply with the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of buildings and for the protection of property from injury or destruction by fire".

"Sec. 3. It shall be the duty of the health officer, also of the chief of the fire department, respectively, upon application from any person or persons proposing to open or conduct the business of a public laundry within the City of Seattle to inspect the premises in which it is proposed to carry on said business, or in which said business is being carried on, with a view to ascertain whether the said premises are provided with proper drainage and sanitary appliances, also whether the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of buildings and for the protection of property from injury or destruction by fire, have been complied with, and if found in all respects satisfactory, then to issue to such person or persons the certificates provided for in section 2 of this ordinance. No charge whatever shall be made or compensation or fee collected or received for the performance of any of the services required by the provisions of this ordinance in the inspection of premises or the issuance of a certificate, but all such services shall be performed free of charge".

"Sec. 6. It shall be unlawful, from and after the passage of this ordinance, for any person or persons to establish, maintain or carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the City of Seattle without having first obtained the consent of the common council, except the same be located in a building constructed either of brick

or stone, and covered with a metal roof". The petitioner alleges in substance that an application was made by John Miller, the petitioner's lessor, to the City of Seattle for a permit to change premises No. 1410 East First Street into a laundry; that there were submitted therewith builder' specifications for said change, expressly designating that the same were to be used for laundry purposes; that said application and specifications were examined by the building inspector of the City of Seattle and were duly approved and a permit was granted authorizing the proposed change; that at the time when said laundry permit was granted, the health officer of the City of Seattle, after inspecting said premises, on June 18, 1902, gave his official certificate stating that "permission is given to John Miller to build a laundry at 1410 East First Street, he having complied with the said ordinance"; that pursuant to said respective permits, the petitioner expended upwards of $600 in making said changes and converting said building into one suitable for laundry purposes; that at the conclusion of said work, on Aug. 2, 1902, the health officer of Seattle executed a certificate, certifying that he had inspected the premises and found them properly and sufficiently drained and that proper provisions had been made for sanitary conditions. That on July 30, 1902, the city inspector of plumbing for said city certified that the plumbing in said building had been inspected, completed, and found to be in accordance with the ordinance of the City of Seattle; that notwithstanding these facts, certain persons made petition to the common council of the City of Seattle against having at the designated place a "Chinese laundry", and requested the council to withold their consent for the same; that the petitione was indorsed: "A remonstrance against erecting a Chinese laundry at No. 1410 East First Street", and was referred to a committee of the council who, without giving the petitioner a hearing, reported a recommendation that the council

refuse to grant its consent to said laundry, which report was adopted by the council. It appears from these allegations that the reason why the council withheld its consent to the maintainance of the petitioner's laundry was that it was to be a Chinese laundry. The petitioner contends that by said action of the council a discrimination unfavorable to him was made, for no reason save that he is a Chinaman, and that his arrest and detention are unlawful for the reason that they contravene the provisions of the 14th amendment in that they deprive him of his liberty and property without due process of law and deny him the equal protection of the laws. It is clear that Sec. 6 of the ordinance above quoted gives to the common council of the City of Seattle the arbitrary power to withhold permission from any person or persons to conduct a laundry within the coporate limits of the city unless it be located in a building constructed of brick or stone and covered with a metal roof. That such an ordinance is unlawful has been decided by the Supreme Court, in Yick Wo v. Hopkins, 118 U.S., 356, as well as in several decisions at the Circuit. Referring to the ordinance in that case, which was similar to that which is under consideration in the case at bar, the court said: "It does not prescribe a rule and conditions for the regulation of the use of property for laundry purposes, to which all similarly situated may conform. It allows without restriction the use for such purposes of buildings of brick and stone; but, as to wooden buildings, constituting nearly all those in previous use, it divides the owners or occupiers into two classes, not having respect to their personal character and qualifications for the business, nor the situation and nature and adaptation of the buildings themselves, but merely by an arbitrary line, on one side of which are those who are permitted to pursue their industry by the mere will and consent of the

supervisors, and on the other those from whom that consent is withheld at their mere will and pleasure..... The ordinance, therefore, also differs from the not unusual case, where discretion is lodged by law in public officers or bodies to grant or withhold licenses to keep taverns, or places for the sale of spirituous liquors, and the like, when one of the conditions is that the applicant shall be a fit person for the exercise of the privilege, because in such cases the fact of fitness is submitted to the judgment of the officer, and calls for the exercise of a discretion of a judicial nature."

But it is contended that the doctrine of the Yick Wo case is modified by the more recent decision of the Supreme Court in Gundling v. Chicago, 177 U.S., 183. In that case it was held that an ordinance authorizing the issuance of licenses to persons to sell cigarettes and forbidding their sale without license was constitutional, but the ordinance differs from that in the Yick Wo case and from that which is under consideration in the present case in that it required that the applications for license be accompanied by evidence that the applicant was a person of good moral character and reputation and required that the application and the evidence accompanying the same should be submitted by the commissioner of health, together with his own opinion concerning the propriety of granting such a license, to the may and that if the mayor should be satisfied that the applicant was of good moral character and reputation, and suitable to be intrusted with the sale of cigarettes, the license should issue upon the execution of a bond with sureties. The court pointed out the distinction between that case and the Yick Wo case and alluded to the fact that the ordinance in the Yick Wo case was held to be illegal and violative of the 14th amendment, because with reference to the subject upon which it touched, "it conferred upon the municipal authorities arbitrary power at their will and without regard to discretion in the legal sense of the term,

to give or withhold consent as to persons or places for carrying on a laundry with reference to the competency of the persons applying or the propriety of the place selected. It was also held that there was a clear and intentional discrimination made against the Chinese in the operation of the ordinance, which discrimination was founded upon the difference of race and was wholly arbitrary and unjust".

It is contended also that the present case may be differentiated from the Yick Wo case by reading into the terms of Sec. 6 of the ordinance the provisions of Sections 2 and 3, but that contention cannot be sustained. Sections 2 and 3 make general proovisions regulating the license and maintenance of the laundry business and require arrangements to secure sanitary conditions, drainage, protection against fire and official inspection of the premises. They are generl provisions applicable to all laundries whether in wooden buildings or brick or stone buildings with metal roofs. Sec. 6 is a distinct and separte grant to the council of arbitrary power to withold from any or all persons at will permission to maintain any laundry not located in a building constructed of brick or stone and covered with a metal roof. With the violtion of that ordinance and that ordinance alone, the petitioner is charged. The business of conducting a laundry, while it is subject to the police power of a municipal corporation, is not in itself a public nuisance and cannot be made such by the mere declaration of a city ordinance. If the petitioner is to be deprived of the right to use his property in the prosecution of a legitimate business, not dangerous or injurious to oters, he can only be so deprived by a judgment of competent authority, pronounced in the exercise of a judicial discretion so vested as to observe due process of law and afford him the equal protection of the laws.
Upon the allegations of the petition, th writ must issue as prayed for.
